Description: Fragment of large plate or dish, carved from fine-grained black and white hard stone, likely serpentine; preserved complete profile of this thick-walled shallow vessel with a flat, offset rim and delineated base; smooth outer and inner surfaces.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Redpath Museum, Montreal. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The type of serpentine used for this plate, granular black, is mainly documented for stone vessels dated to the Middle Kingdom and the Second Intermediate Period, though a post New Kingdom vessel in such material is attested (Aston 1994, 59, type C serpentine). Bar the three fragments of vessel in serpentine, all kept in Montreal Redpath Museum (2469.1-3), Naukratis provided a few weights and tools in serpentine (or alleged to be serpentine). Aston, B. G. 1994, Ancient Egyptian stone vessels: materials and forms, Heidelberg.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (EA.156) (phase 3)
